ThingDef.label: Lee Enfield N°4 MkI
ThingDef.description: Great Britain. The Lee Enfield N°4 MkI is the standard-issued infantry rifle of the Common Wealth Forces during WWII. It's precise and have a really good rate of fire for a bolt-action rifle. A weapon of choice.

ThingDef.label: LeeEnfield N°1 MkIII
ThingDef.description: Great Britain. The Lee Enfield N°1 MkIII is the standard-issued infantry rifle of the Common Wealth Forces during WWI. It's precise and have a really good rate of fire for a bolt-action rifle. A weapon of choice.

ThingDef.label: LeeEnfield N°1 MkIII scoped
ThingDef.description: Great Britain. A Lee Enfield N°1 MkIII but scoped.

ThingDef.label: LeeEnfield N°4 MkI (T)
ThingDef.description: Great Britain. The Lee Enfield N°4 Mk1 (T) a more precise and well made version of the standard-issued infantry rifle. The Ts were selected at the testing range for theire spectacular precision and was then outfited with a sniper kit and ussed to snipers unit. It's one of the best of its kind.

ThingDef.label: L1A1
ThingDef.description: Commonwealth. A powerful AR but heavy and not controllable in full-auto, So soldiers generally don't use it that way.

ThingDef.label: Lewis Gun
ThingDef.description: Great Britain. A US designed LMG, served the UK greatly during the Great War and continue during WWII but more on secondary roles.

ThingDef.label: Bren MkII
ThingDef.description: Great Britain. The Bren is a magazin-fed LMG, reliable, a bit heavy but extremely popular among the men that used it, on foot or on vehicle.

ThingDef.label: Thompson M1928 (drum mag)
ThingDef.description: USA. The Thompson M1928 is the classic 30s gangster-style SMG, well build and reliable but heavy and really expensive to make. This one is the 50 rounds mag version.

ThingDef.label: Thompson M1928 (stick mag)
ThingDef.description: USA. The Thompson M1928 is the classic 30s gangster-style SMG, well build and reliable but heavy and really expensive to make. This one is the 50 rounds mag version.

ThingDef.label: Sten MkII
ThingDef.description: Great Britain. Created in a hurry by the UK to equip its own forces, it was massively droped to the Resistance during the War. It's really really cheap to make and quite light. However its buttstock is not the best for precise shooting.

ThingDef.label: Sten MkIII
ThingDef.description: Great Britain. Created in a hurry by the UK to equip its own forces, it was massively droped to the Resistance during the War. It's really really cheap to make. The MkIII is a bit more robust

ThingDef.label: Sten MkVI
ThingDef.description: Great Britain. Created in a hurry by the UK to equip its own forces, The Sten variants were massively droped to the Resistance during the War. It's really really cheap to make. The MkVI is the final upgrade of the gun given to the paratroopers, its wooden buttsock and pistol grips make it way more accurate.

ThingDef.label: Owen
ThingDef.description: Australia. A pretty ugly gun but a really good SMG : simple to make, reliable and easy to shoot.

ThingDef.label: Webley
ThingDef.description: Great Britain. The trusty revolver of british officers a tank crew for a big part of the 20th century. It have a good stopping power due to its ‎.455 cartridge.

ThingDef.label: PIAT
ThingDef.description: Great Britain. The PIAT is an anti-tank weapon. Its projectile is propelled by the force of a spring in the weapon. It's cheaper and more discreet but the range is way shorter than a rocket-propelled anti-tank grenade.
